Bottom line is all vehicles face challenges from extreme cold - whether EV or traditional gasoline.

EVs do experience a loss of range in the cold, but most still provide enough for most households, and it’s not the dealbreaker some have made it out to be.

🗺 What about range?
There is indeed a decline in range in cold weather, from 20-40%. This is mostly from the extra power used to warm the cabin. 

It is important to remember though, that even with this limitation, the range of most EVs is more than enough for most households.

🔌 The issue with 🔋 performance is address by using power from the grid to warm precondition the battery. 

♨️ Another great feature of EVs is the ability to preheat the cabin using car from the grid. Unlike gasoline cars, which need to idle and waste gas to warm up.

💥 We’ve all had trouble starting our gasoline vehicle in -30°C. This is because
🔋 battery performance declines
🛢 motor oil thickens
🧊 fuel line may even freeze

⚡️EVs actually start better in the cold!
The 2nd and 3rd points aren’t an issue with EVs.

❄️📉 All vehicles, including gasoline vehicles, have some decline in performance in cold weather. 🚙💨

🍒🤏 EV skeptics exaggerate the cold weather limitations of EVs, while ignoring the limitations of traditional gas cars.

🥶 With the extreme cold in Alberta, good time to fight the myth that electric vehicles are not suitable for cold climates. 🇨🇦
